channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Hedge Funds: A Poor Choice for Most Long-Term Investors?
item.description: By allocating to a diversified pool of hedge funds, many institutional investors are unwittingly reducing their equity holdings.

item.title: Sam’s Club is going after Costco through the hearts and wallets of Gen Z shoppers. ‘That generation believes it’s cool to save money,’ CEO says
item.description: The Walmart-owned retailer’s digital strategies and budget brands have struck a chord with tech-savvy and deal-driven Gen Z.

item.title: Did Inflation Kill the CAPM?
item.description: While the immediate future may not be promising for the equity premium, it looks bright for factor premiums.

item.title: Doctors in Idaho can now provide emergency abortions, SCOTUS rules, after pregnant women were airlifted out of the state for emergency care
item.description: The ruling came a day after an opinion was briefly posted on the court's website accidentally and quickly taken down, but not before it was obtained by Bloomberg News.

item.title: Behavior of Crowds not Wisdom of Crowds
item.description: When behavioral crowds are roiling the markets, as they are now, best idea active equity has an excellent chance of outperforming.

item.title: Ellevest’s founder went to Wall Street after being rejected by her first choice. Now her $2 billion empire is helping women build their own wealth
item.description: The investing industry tends to look past women and mostly serve men, longtime Wall Street executive Sallie Krawcheck says. That's what led her to build Ellevest.

item.title: Is the Outright Ban on a US Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) a Mistake?
item.description: Instead of outright banning a US CBDC, wouldn’t it be preferrable to establish clear and enforceable legislative guardrails?

item.title: The Supreme Court just rejected a deal with the maker of OxyContin that would have shielded the billionaire Sackler family from liability—but provided billions of dollars to fight opioids
item.description: Had the bankruptcy been approved, the Sacklers would have contributed up to $6 billion and given up ownership of the company but retained billions more.

item.title: Concerned About Market Concentration and Lofty Valuations? Consider Small Caps
item.description: Investors are showing increased concern about large-cap stocks due to high market concentration and lofty stock valuations. Other factors combine to make a compelling case for small caps.

item.title: Cybersecurity is now a ‘team sport’ amid a wave of generative AI-based attacks, say tech experts
item.description: AI "is available to both our friends and foes," warned Maria Milosavljevic, group CISO at ANZ Banking Group, at a Fortune conversation Wednesday.
